name: Kusimanse (Dark Mongoose)
description: This relatively small mongoose has a noticeably elongated snout and long claws on its forelegs. Its fur is rather coarse, with brownish guard hairs tipped with yellow, giving it a distinctive tipped appearance. The legs are blackish-brown.
spread_note: West Africa - Ghana, Liberia, Sierra Leone, Guinea
food_note: Small vertebrates and various invertebrates, partly also ripe fruits
proportions: Body length 44–56 cm; tail length 14.5–25.8 cm; weight 0.5–1 kg
reproduction: Females are pregnant for an average of 58 days and bear 2–4 young
attractions: Dark mongooses (also known as kusimanse) are as social as savanna mongoose species, living in family groups of 10–20 individuals. The family occupies a territory marked with scent gland secretions and defended against outsider mongooses. When foraging, they use their long claws and snouts to turn over leaf litter, stones, and branches, or climb low trees and hunt crabs and other aquatic or muddy creatures in shallows.
